content.webTitle: Victoria Moore: Whites to drink with clean-tasting food

fields.headline: Whites to drink with clean-tasting food
fields.bodyText: Some of you have asked where you can find the health-giving red wines about which Professor Roger Corder writes in The Wine Diet (Sphere, £9.99), a book whose title sounds (and is) a little too good to be true, although his opening - "Wine drinkers are generally healthier and often live longer. This is not just wishful thinking ... wine drinkers have less heart disease and diabetes and are less likely to suffer from dementia" - does raise the spirits. This is not to say that binge-drinkers (and half a bottle a day puts you in that category) are safe. But Corder has identified a compound, procyanidin, a type of polyphenol, abundant in some red wines (and in cranberries, pomegranates and walnuts), that has what he calls a "potent positive effect on blood vessels" and so is good for the heart. Among the wines he found to be especially rich in procyanidins are several from producers I've recommended before - the big beast that is Château le Cedre Cuvée le Cedre (£22.44, Caves de Pyrene, near Guildford), say, and the delicious Domaine de l'Hortus Grand Cuvée Pic St Loup (£12.04, Caves de Pyrene, H&H Bancroft). Corder pays special attention to the wines of Madiran and Côtes de Saint Mont - tannic, challenging, extreme wines based on the tannat grape which as much resemble a Blossom Hill red as a pterodactyl does a jelly baby. I tried a handful - unyielding, heavy characters - of which I was most taken by the relatively accessible Château de Sabazan 2003, Côtes de Saint-Mont, France (£12.99, Nicolas, Grape Ideas, Bedales) and, despite the grotesquery of its metal label and red wax seal, the dusty Madiran Plénitude 2001 (around £14.99, Bedales, Adnams). But I can't help feeling it might be easier to take the procyanidins from food, and drink purely for pleasure and at whim. Hence these white wines, which are cheaper and picked to match with clean foods, in case you're still trying to be healthy. A Passoni Vernaccia di San Gimignano 2005, Italy Stockists £6.99, or £6.49 if you buy two or more up to February 5, Majestic Description Crisp acidity, richly fruity but in a rather wintery way - reminiscent of cool apples and early shoots, with a touch of pearskin and a strong herbaceous undertow. Drink it with Watercress, pear, fennel and chicory salad. Score 3.5/5 Darting Estate, Dürkheimer Michelsberg Riesling 2005, Germany Stockists £5.24, down from £6.99 until January 29, Marks & Spencer Description An impressive, dry German riesling that is friskily full of life and movement. Drink it with Sushi. Score 4/5 Leasingham, The Magnus Riesling 2005, Clare Valley, Australia Stockists Around £7.49, Sainsbury, Somerfield; £7.99, Thresher, or £5.33 when you buy three or more Description Clare Valley is one of the best areas in Australia for riesling, and this is a dry, vivid, invigorating example. Drink it with Match the limey shock of this wine against pork cooked with cashews, chillies and lime juice, served with rice. Score 3.5/5 Tesco Finest, Denman Estate Semillon 2005, Hunter Valley, Australia Stockists £7.99, Tesco Description A mouthwateringly good introduction to the vivid, grassy, low-ish alcohol semillons from the Hunter Valley, to the north of Sydney. Drink it with Soft shell crab springs to mind, but that's impractical so try fish kebabs marinated in lemon and garlic instead. Score 3.5/5 · victoriamoore2004@hotmail.com
